issue.title: Generate tsconfig files from higher level description
issue.body: Currently we maintain tsconfig.json and a tsconfig-watch.json configuration file hierarchy. We actually need a third one for publishing since we should publish with different compiler settings. To avoid another hierarchy of settings we need to maintain by hand we should have a generator that creates these configuration files on the fly.

issue.title: Pull diagnostics not cleared when file deleted
issue.body:
With workspace diagnostic support enabled, diagnostics for a file are not cleared when the file is deleted (either through VSCode or externally). The diagnostics remain in the problems tab.

This issue becomes more apparent when using commands like `git stash`

issue.title: The client throws an error `read ECONNRESET` during server debugging
issue.body:
When I step debugging the `completionProvider` of the LSP server and run the `RegExp match`, the LSP client triggers the `handleConnectionError` due to `read ECONNRESET` and the server is stopped.

But this does not happen when I add a break-point on the line following the `RegExp match`.

issue.title: The client throws an error `read ECONNRESET` during server debugging
issue.body:
When I step debugging the `completionProvider` of the LSP server and run the `RegExp match`, the LSP client triggers the `handleConnectionError` due to `read ECONNRESET` and the server is stopped.

But this does not happen when I add a break-point on the line following the `RegExp match`.

comment.body: Thanks for reaching back. I will close the issue for now. Please ping if you see it again.

issue.title: The initial execution of a Python file is slow again
issue.body: Need to investigate why this is happening again.

comment.body:
Actually,  `vscode-python-web-wasm` will change frequently since it host currently both the default python installation and the extension code. We could move the default python installation into another repository but that would look strange from a repository point of view.

I am actually for option (ii). I do for example load the wasm file into shared memory (and cache it there) so that I don't need to copy it into the worker on every run. Since a sync can happen at any time I would need to drop the WASM file again and reload it into shared memory. For that I would need the event.

pull_request.title: Bump nokogiri from 1.13.9 to 1.13.10
pull_request.body:
Bumps [nokogiri](https://github.com/sparklemotion/nokogiri) from 1.13.9 to 1.13.10.
Release notes

Sourced from nokogiri's releases.

1.13.10 / 2022-12-07

Security

  • [CRuby] Address CVE-2022-23476, unchecked return value from xmlTextReaderExpand. See GHSA-qv4q-mr5r-qprj for more information.

Improvements

  • [CRuby] XML::Reader#attribute_hash now returns nil on parse errors. This restores the behavior of #attributes from v1.13.7 and earlier. [#2715]

issue.title: Perform websocket request during onDefinition
issue.body:
When `connection.onDefinition` is invoked, I'm hoping to send a websocket request and await its response before returning the definition `Location`, which takes the user to that location in VS Code. The execution of `connection.onDefinition` completes before the websocket request/response finishes.

I've experimented with using a callback function. First, by having the callback return the desired `Location`, but that does not trigger that location to open in VS Code. Secondly, I tried having the callback invoke `connection.onDefinition` with updated parameters, and making sure to return the `Location` in this case, but that also does not jump the user to the definition location.

Is it possible to achieve this? Or is there simply no way currently to delay the execution of `connection.onDefinition` or invoke it a subsequent time using a callback function?

comment.body: Yes all request callback can return a Promise which will be awaited before the response is sent back.

issue.title: Header field name in jsonrpc Message has to be case-insensitive
issue.body:
Hi! I'm working on building protobuf language server in Deno and its extension for vscode.

I found that the header part of LSP message conforms to the HTTP semantic in [LSP docs](https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/specification-3-17/#headerPart).

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/f72faa0975cb2aaa85ce84da819944f84e1aac52/jsonrpc/src/common/messageBuffer.ts#L94
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/f72faa0975cb2aaa85ce84da819944f84e1aac52/jsonrpc/src/common/messageReader.ts#L218
But `tryReadHeaders` and its usage in `messageReader` show that the header field name seems to be case-sensitive.

I think the return object of `tryReadHeaders` has to be implemented like `Headers` in Web API, or any other object that can get a header value with case-insensitive name.

issue.title: Working extension inexplicably stopped sending document symbols
issue.body:
I'm working on developing an extension for VSCode that utilizes this language server library. I've gotten to the point where I'm able to successfully respond to the `onDocumentSymbol()` hook. [Here's the server.ts file in my repo](https://github.com/japhib/pico8-ls/blob/master/server/src/server.ts) -- a fairly simple implementation, following [this guide](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/language-extensions/language-server-extension-guide).

However, after getting it to work in my test workspace, the "go to symbol" action then mysteriously _stopped_ working. No indication of an error -- no loading indicator, no "symbols are not available," just "no editor symbols." 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11890284/150730396-f06f5654-2643-4da1-bbdc-9970cd3b697b.png)

If I enable tracing for my extension, I can clearly see the document symbol request getting sent to my language server, and then returned back to the extension client with a huge list of symbols for the file I had open.

I had made some code changes, but when I reverted all those code changes and went back to the previous state of the repo, **it still did not work.**

So I thought, alright, maybe there's some config in my VSCode or something about the installation got in a weird place. So I went ahead and uninstalled VSCode completely (I'm on mac, so I deleted it from /Applications/ and also `rm -rf`'ed a bunch of folders [as described here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42603103/how-to-completely-uninstall-vscode-on-mac)) and then re-installed it. I'm still getting the same behavior after re-installation.

The really vexing thing is that as soon as I try it on another computer, **it still works.** Just like I had it working before. I get a big list of document symbols exactly as expected.

So my question is, how do I even begin debugging this? Is there some verbose error logging I can enable? Do I need to clone this repo locally, reference it in my project, and add a bunch of `console.log`? Any suggestions appreciated. I'm also happy to provide more details if needed. Thanks.

* Fixes #897: Header field name in jsonrpc Message has to be case-insensitive

issue.title: Stream read errors result in uncaught exceptions
issue.body:
`ReadableStreamMessageReader` throws exceptions if `Content-Length` is invalid, which end up as uncaught exceptions instead of going through `onError`. See the tests in #871 for an example. Without the try/catch, the test fails:

```
  1) Messages
       Read without Content-Length:
     Uncaught Error: Header must provide a Content-Length property.
      at StreamMessageReader.onData (lib/common/messageReader.js:137:27)
      at Readable.<anonymous> (lib/common/messageReader.js:121:18)
      at Readable.read (_stream_readable.js:512:10)
      at flow (_stream_readable.js:985:34)
      at resume_ (_stream_readable.js:966:3)
      at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:84:21)

  2) Messages
       Read with invalid Content-Length:
     Uncaught Error: Content-Length value must be a number.
      at StreamMessageReader.onData (lib/common/messageReader.js:141:27)
      at Readable.<anonymous> (lib/common/messageReader.js:121:18)
      at Readable.read (_stream_readable.js:512:10)
      at flow (_stream_readable.js:985:34)
      at resume_ (_stream_readable.js:966:3)
      at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:84:21)
```

This was previously reported in #270, but it has not been fixed.

issue.title: Add a postinstall script to check minimum VSCode requirement
issue.body: If vscode-languageclient requires a newer VSCode version than the user has specified in his extension's `package.json`, an error message should be printed. This would help prevent accidental broken releases (see this discussion for more info: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/commit/f5542d9f912e5a54b6bc81ae2df0d12cf7ee9082#r37530736).

issue.title: If diagnostics is CodeAction is `null` or `undefined` you Cannot read properties of null (reading 'map')
issue.body:
From Protocol definition of CodeAction `diagnostics` is optional:
```json
                {
                    "name": "diagnostics",
                    "type": {
                        "kind": "array",
                        "element": {
                            "kind": "reference",
                            "name": "Diagnostic"
                        }
                    },
                    "optional": true,
                    "documentation": "The diagnostics that this code action resolves."
                },
```

issue.title: Inconsistent Interface for CompletionItem
issue.body:
What is the intended approach to create a ```CompletionItem``` that replaces text?

I would like the completion to replace the entire line where the users cursor is currently located.

When I specify the text and range as a ```TextEdit``` the range seems to be ignored and instead the default current word range is used.
```
const completionItem = {
    label: 'competion item label',
    kind: CompletionItemKind.Text,
    textEdit: TextEdit.replace('new text', range),
}
```

I did a little digging and it looks like in the VS Code API interfaces ```textEdit``` is deprecated with the message ```Use `CompletionItem.insertText` and `CompletionItem.range` instead.```
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vscode-dts/vscode.d.ts#L4515

In the commit that deprecated ```textEdit``` it looks like the range is being ignored which is consistent with what I am experiencing.
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/c76b721d819648431799f9b38bae80e4e2054cf9

However, the ```CompletionItem``` interface in ```vscode-languageserver-node``` does not have a range property. Does that interface need to be updated?

comment.body:
Actually, this is on purpose. These types are defined by JSONRPC and a generation tool could rely on a library to provide them (e.g. even in LSP we have the protocol which depends on vscode-jsonrpc, which defines these types).

I will close the issue since I think that the meta model shouldn't define these.

issue.title: JSON RPC Protocol operator "??"  in compiled js files
issue.body:
### The problem

The package `vscode-jsonrpc` does not comply with the es2018 standard. 

For "proprietary packages" describing the protocol, it would be nice to be able to build parent project without additional library transpilation. Now, to bring it to the es2018 standard, an additional run of all the code through babel or something like that is required.

Compiled file witn issue https://unpkg.com/vscode-jsonrpc@8.0.1/lib/common/connection.js
Source file https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/main/jsonrpc/src/common/connection.ts#L731

### Expectations

Bundled js files shouldn't have `??` or anything non es2018 features.

Phobia test results contains error as well, bcause cannot works witn nullish operator `??` see here https://bundlephobia.com/package/vscode-jsonrpc@8.0.1

issue.title: It's should be possible to `start()` a LanguageClient that failed previously.
issue.body:
My use case is the following:

I have a plugin which will read the settings to start from the configuration (i.e.: executable / arguments), so, whenever those settings are changed, the `LanguageClient` is restarted.

This works well enough, but if the user has some wrong setting (say, he mistyped the executable) then an error will be raised when starting the Language (the `ServerOptions` passed to the `LanguageClient` is a function which is called when the `LanguageClient` is started, but in this case it'll throw an error -- afterwards, trying to call `LanguageClient.start()` or `LanguageClient.stop()` will always just reraise the same error and the function passed as the `ServerOptions` will not be called again).

Tested with `"vscode-languageclient": "^7.0.0"` and `"vscode-languageclient": "^8.0.0-next.7"`.

Note: not sure if it makes a difference, but in this scenario the `LanguageClient` was started successfully once, then the user made changes to make the error happen and then when fixing it to have the proper settings it won't work (because it has failed the previous time and calls to `stop` and `start` just reraise the previous error instead of calling the function passed as `ServerOptions`).

issue.body:
When ESLint fails to load a plugin it gives 3 suggestions:

```
Failed to load plugin '@typescript-eslint' declared in 'frontend/.eslintrc': Cannot find module '@typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin'
Require stack:
- /Users/brady/Dev/tiamat/member_webapp_frontend/__placeholder__.js
Referenced from: /Users/brady/Dev/tiamat/member_webapp_frontend/frontend/.eslintrc
Happened while validating /Users/brady/Dev/tiamat/member_webapp_frontend/frontend/src/modules/admin/pages/tests/AdminReportsPage.test.tsx
This can happen for a couple of reasons:

1. The plugin name is spelled incorrectly in an ESLint configuration file (e.g. .eslintrc).
2. If ESLint is installed globally, then make sure '@typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin' is installed globally as well.
3. If ESLint is installed locally, then '@typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin' isn't installed correctly.

issue.title: Allow specifying nearest config directory as working directory

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
Currently, I can specify that the eslint working directory should be
- workspace folder
- linted file directory
- "auto" inferred (the meaning of which is not very clear)
- specific sets of directories or directory globs

Consider a layout for an Angular project that uses Nightwatch for end-to-end testing. Nightwatch uses property names for some configuration options that need to be quoted like e.g. `ms:edgeOptions`. I want to enforce that code we write in typescript uses `camelCase` properties, but the `nigtwatch.conf.js` file (which needs to be JS not TS for reasons I don't understand - but at least that makes the pathspec easy to wildcard) needs to relax that constraint.

So, the directories look like
```
- nightwatch/
    - nightwatch.conf.json
    - .eslintrc.json
    - tsconfig.e2e.json
    - globals/
        - globals.ts
    - page_objects/
        - a-page.ts
    - tests/
        - page.spec.ts
- angular.json
- .eslintrc.json
- tsconfig.json
- package.json
- node_modules/...
- src/
    - app/
        - app.component.ts
    - index.html
```
... where `nightwatch/.eslintrc.json` extends the root `.eslintrc.json`.

And I have a workspace open to the root of this project. To get the Typescript ESLint plugin parser working, I have `overrides[0].parserOptions.project` set to `["tsconfig.e2e.json"]`. Running ESLint manually from within the `nightwatch/` directory picks up all the proper rules and lints appropriately. Running ESLint manually from the project root properly uses the nightwatch config for that directory and the root config for everything else. The ESLint VSCod(e/ium) plugin, however, fails to lint any files under `nightwatch/` because
```
Parsing error: Cannot read file '/path/to/project/root/tsconfig.e2e.json'.
```
(also fwiw `ng lint` works exactly correctly as well).

That's because - I assume - the plugin is trying to run ESLint from the project root but specifying the configuration file as the one in the directory it's trying to lint. As a manual ESLint command, it would look like `npx eslint -c ./nightwatch/.eslintrc.json ./nightwatch `. That command fails with the same messages that the plugin gives me.

Instead, ESLint should allow me to configure it to use the directory containing the `.eslintrc.json` file it's using as the working directory.

Interestingly, in both "location" and "auto" modes, if I change the `nightwatch/.eslintrc.json`'s `overrides[0].parserOptions.project` to `["nightwatch/tsconfig.e2e.json"]`, first of all it starts to successfully lint files under `nightwatch/` - but then if I change that property _back_ to just `["tsconfig.e2e.json"]` it'll keep successfully linting those files. I have no idea why it can "fix" itself like this and only after I manually intervene.

comment.body:
Reading through it again I think there is nothing the extension can do since the working directory determines the search path start not the other way around. The current behavior is as follows:

- no working directories specified: the workspace folder is used as a working directory. The base name of the file path is used as a starting directory for searching for config files / node modules
- a working directory is specified: it is used. The base name of the file path is used as a starting directory for searching for config files / node modules
- auto: The base name of the file path is used as a starting directory for searching for config files / node modules. If a config filer is found in one of the parent directories then that directory is used as a working directory.

I will close the issue. Please ping if you think that the current behavior is not sufficient.

issue.title: Lint task: doesn't work without `node_modules` in workspace folder

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
I am working on a multiplayer game project, and the client- and server-side logic are included in separate root folders of my repository. Only the server-side folder contains TypeScript code, and therefore only that folder has the usual config files like `package.json` and `.eslintrc.js` file, and only that folder has `node_modules/`; there is no `node_modules/` folder at the root. The `lint whole folder` task does not work under these circumstances. Regardless of what paths I pass to the `eslint.options`, `eslint.workingDirectories`, or `eslint.lintTask.options` settings, the task always fails with:

>/usr/bin/bash: eslint: command not found
The terminal process "bash '-c', 'eslint .'" failed to launch (exit code: 127).

Looking through your source, it appears that the issue is in the [utils.findEslint](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-eslint/blob/a0172c8645dd790df32a6c2b6436855eff470775/client/src/utils.ts#L18) function. It looks for `<rootPath>/node_modules/.bin/eslint.cmd` on win32 platforms, else `<rootPath>/node_modules/.bin/eslint` on linux, else a global `eslint`. `<rootPath>`, in turn, is apparently set to the root workspace folder in the [`FolderTaskProvider` constructor](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-eslint/blob/a0172c8645dd790df32a6c2b6436855eff470775/client/src/tasks.ts#L15). So in my setup (repo opened under WSL2 on Windows 10, with no globally installed eslint package), the task fails b/c it can't find the local eslint in my server folder.

I considered opening a PR for this myself, but it will probably require a new config option, and that doesn't seem like my decision to make. 😛 Any other workarounds that I might've missed would be much appreciated!

issue.title: "lint whole folder" task ignores eslint.rules.customizations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
In my settings file I have:
```
"eslint.rules.customizations": [{ "rule": "*", "severity": "downgrade" }]
```

When I run "eslint: lint whole folder", however, eslint errors show up as errors in the Problems panel. If I click on one of those errors, then the offending file is opened, the regular eslint process runs that file, and all issues that were reporting as errors are switched (because of the customizations) to reporting as warnings. Shouldn't the lint whole folder task look at customizations and show those issues as warnings in the first place?

issue.title: Ambiguous "Extension 'ESLint' cannot format x" error if eslint not installed

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
I think that the error you get if you haven't installed eslint is a little ambiguous and making it more specific would help diagnose the problem faster.

I cloned a monorepo which has eslint as a dependency at the top level and then individual packages in subfolders. I remembered to run `npm install` in the sub-package folders but forgot to run it in the root folder. When trying to format a file I was seeing this error:

> Extension 'ESLint' cannot format '*.js'

Opening the eslint output pane I saw nothing to indicate anything was wrong, the complete output was:

> [Info  - 12:13:06 pm] ESLint server stopped.
> [Info  - 12:13:06 pm] ESLint server running in node v14.16.0
> [Info  - 12:13:06 pm] ESLint server is running.

After googling and reading issues for a while I eventually remembered what I'd forgotten to do, but a specific error indicating that eslint was not found in this case would be really helpful for spotting the problem.

issue.title: Add a "search paths" option

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
Currently, this extension has a `eslint.nodePath` option that allows specifying a known directory for finding the `eslint` executable. This does not solve a very specific problem for me:

I have a project that looks like:

```
❯ tree -L 4
.
├── index.js
├── node_modules
│   └── standard
│       ├── AUTHORS.md
│       ├── CHANGELOG.md
│       ├── LICENSE
│       ├── README.md
│       ├── RULES.md
│       ├── bin
│       │   └── cmd.js
│       ├── eslintrc.json
│       ├── index.js
│       ├── node_modules
│       │   ├── eslint
│       │   ├── eslint-config-standard
│       │   ├── eslint-config-standard-jsx
│       │   ├── eslint-plugin-import
│       │   ├── eslint-plugin-node
│       │   ├── eslint-plugin-promise
│       │   ├── eslint-plugin-react
│       │   └── standard-engine
│       ├── options.js
│       └── package.json
└── package.json

12 directories, 12 files
```

Notice that the `eslint` package is in a nested `node_modules` directory. This means the VSCode extension will not find the executable and thus will not show lint errors or automatically fix errors on save within this project.

What I would like to see is an option like `eslint.searchPaths = []` which could be altered to something like:

```js
eslint.searchPaths = ['built-in', `${workspaceDir}/node_modules/standard/node_modules`]
```

Where the special "buit-in" string would include the current paths that the extension searches.

I think this issue is very similar to #1286 but not quite the same.

---

**.npmrc**
```
save-prefix=^
package-lock=false
```

**package.json**
```json
{
  "devDependencies": {
    "standard": "^16.0.3"
  }
}
```

**index.js**
```js
'use strict';

function thisFileHasLintErrors() {
return true
}

thisFileHasLintErrors()

```

issue.title: Adding another Disable Rule Comment through VSCode's Quick FIx options causes the rules to be re-enabled
issue.body:
**Problem Statement**
If a disable rule comment has already present for a particular line, and when we add another disable rule comment through vscode's quick-fix option,  a separate new comment is added below the previous one. This causes the previous rule to be re-enabled for the concerned line.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15160343/117317127-dbc72e00-aea6-11eb-8518-62505ad8ebc0.png)

Similar behaviour happens when `eslint.codeAction.disableRuleComment.location` has been set to `sameLine`. The new disable rule comment is appended to the existing disable rule comment present.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15160343/117317421-22b52380-aea7-11eb-82c4-84c49131ca23.png)


**Expected Behaviour**
If there is any preexisting disable rule comment for any particular line and another rule is being disabled for that same line, instead of creating or appending the comment, only the rule should be appended to the existing disable rule comment, separated by comma(s). Like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15160343/117317850-83446080-aea7-11eb-8417-33949fd7f207.png)


The same behavior is observed when disabling multiple rules for entire files as well, but it doesn't cause any rule to be re-enabled

I would like to work on the fix for this too.

issue.title: Generate tsconfig files from higher level description
issue.body: Currently we maintain tsconfig.json and a tsconfig-watch.json configuration file hierarchy. We actually need a third one for publishing since we should publish with different compiler settings. To avoid another hierarchy of settings we need to maintain by hand we should have a generator that creates these configuration files on the fly.

issue.title: Pull diagnostics not cleared when file deleted
issue.body:
With workspace diagnostic support enabled, diagnostics for a file are not cleared when the file is deleted (either through VSCode or externally). The diagnostics remain in the problems tab.

This issue becomes more apparent when using commands like `git stash`

issue.title: The client throws an error `read ECONNRESET` during server debugging
issue.body:
When I step debugging the `completionProvider` of the LSP server and run the `RegExp match`, the LSP client triggers the `handleConnectionError` due to `read ECONNRESET` and the server is stopped.

But this does not happen when I add a break-point on the line following the `RegExp match`.

issue.title: The client throws an error `read ECONNRESET` during server debugging
issue.body:
When I step debugging the `completionProvider` of the LSP server and run the `RegExp match`, the LSP client triggers the `handleConnectionError` due to `read ECONNRESET` and the server is stopped.

But this does not happen when I add a break-point on the line following the `RegExp match`.

comment.body: Thanks for reaching back. I will close the issue for now. Please ping if you see it again.

issue.title: The initial execution of a Python file is slow again
issue.body: Need to investigate why this is happening again.

comment.body:
Actually,  `vscode-python-web-wasm` will change frequently since it host currently both the default python installation and the extension code. We could move the default python installation into another repository but that would look strange from a repository point of view.

I am actually for option (ii). I do for example load the wasm file into shared memory (and cache it there) so that I don't need to copy it into the worker on every run. Since a sync can happen at any time I would need to drop the WASM file again and reload it into shared memory. For that I would need the event.

issue.title: Perform websocket request during onDefinition
issue.body:
When `connection.onDefinition` is invoked, I'm hoping to send a websocket request and await its response before returning the definition `Location`, which takes the user to that location in VS Code. The execution of `connection.onDefinition` completes before the websocket request/response finishes.

I've experimented with using a callback function. First, by having the callback return the desired `Location`, but that does not trigger that location to open in VS Code. Secondly, I tried having the callback invoke `connection.onDefinition` with updated parameters, and making sure to return the `Location` in this case, but that also does not jump the user to the definition location.

Is it possible to achieve this? Or is there simply no way currently to delay the execution of `connection.onDefinition` or invoke it a subsequent time using a callback function?

comment.body: Yes all request callback can return a Promise which will be awaited before the response is sent back.

issue.title: Header field name in jsonrpc Message has to be case-insensitive
issue.body:
Hi! I'm working on building protobuf language server in Deno and its extension for vscode.

I found that the header part of LSP message conforms to the HTTP semantic in [LSP docs](https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/specification-3-17/#headerPart).

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/f72faa0975cb2aaa85ce84da819944f84e1aac52/jsonrpc/src/common/messageBuffer.ts#L94
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/f72faa0975cb2aaa85ce84da819944f84e1aac52/jsonrpc/src/common/messageReader.ts#L218
But `tryReadHeaders` and its usage in `messageReader` show that the header field name seems to be case-sensitive.

I think the return object of `tryReadHeaders` has to be implemented like `Headers` in Web API, or any other object that can get a header value with case-insensitive name.

issue.title: Working extension inexplicably stopped sending document symbols
issue.body:
I'm working on developing an extension for VSCode that utilizes this language server library. I've gotten to the point where I'm able to successfully respond to the `onDocumentSymbol()` hook. [Here's the server.ts file in my repo](https://github.com/japhib/pico8-ls/blob/master/server/src/server.ts) -- a fairly simple implementation, following [this guide](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/language-extensions/language-server-extension-guide).

However, after getting it to work in my test workspace, the "go to symbol" action then mysteriously _stopped_ working. No indication of an error -- no loading indicator, no "symbols are not available," just "no editor symbols." 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11890284/150730396-f06f5654-2643-4da1-bbdc-9970cd3b697b.png)

If I enable tracing for my extension, I can clearly see the document symbol request getting sent to my language server, and then returned back to the extension client with a huge list of symbols for the file I had open.

I had made some code changes, but when I reverted all those code changes and went back to the previous state of the repo, **it still did not work.**

So I thought, alright, maybe there's some config in my VSCode or something about the installation got in a weird place. So I went ahead and uninstalled VSCode completely (I'm on mac, so I deleted it from /Applications/ and also `rm -rf`'ed a bunch of folders [as described here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42603103/how-to-completely-uninstall-vscode-on-mac)) and then re-installed it. I'm still getting the same behavior after re-installation.

The really vexing thing is that as soon as I try it on another computer, **it still works.** Just like I had it working before. I get a big list of document symbols exactly as expected.

So my question is, how do I even begin debugging this? Is there some verbose error logging I can enable? Do I need to clone this repo locally, reference it in my project, and add a bunch of `console.log`? Any suggestions appreciated. I'm also happy to provide more details if needed. Thanks.

issue.title: Stream read errors result in uncaught exceptions
issue.body:
`ReadableStreamMessageReader` throws exceptions if `Content-Length` is invalid, which end up as uncaught exceptions instead of going through `onError`. See the tests in #871 for an example. Without the try/catch, the test fails:

```
  1) Messages
       Read without Content-Length:
     Uncaught Error: Header must provide a Content-Length property.
      at StreamMessageReader.onData (lib/common/messageReader.js:137:27)
      at Readable.<anonymous> (lib/common/messageReader.js:121:18)
      at Readable.read (_stream_readable.js:512:10)
      at flow (_stream_readable.js:985:34)
      at resume_ (_stream_readable.js:966:3)
      at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:84:21)

  2) Messages
       Read with invalid Content-Length:
     Uncaught Error: Content-Length value must be a number.
      at StreamMessageReader.onData (lib/common/messageReader.js:141:27)
      at Readable.<anonymous> (lib/common/messageReader.js:121:18)
      at Readable.read (_stream_readable.js:512:10)
      at flow (_stream_readable.js:985:34)
      at resume_ (_stream_readable.js:966:3)
      at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:84:21)
```

This was previously reported in #270, but it has not been fixed.

issue.title: Inconsistent Interface for CompletionItem
issue.body:
What is the intended approach to create a ```CompletionItem``` that replaces text?

I would like the completion to replace the entire line where the users cursor is currently located.

When I specify the text and range as a ```TextEdit``` the range seems to be ignored and instead the default current word range is used.
```
const completionItem = {
    label: 'competion item label',
    kind: CompletionItemKind.Text,
    textEdit: TextEdit.replace('new text', range),
}
```

I did a little digging and it looks like in the VS Code API interfaces ```textEdit``` is deprecated with the message ```Use `CompletionItem.insertText` and `CompletionItem.range` instead.```
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vscode-dts/vscode.d.ts#L4515

In the commit that deprecated ```textEdit``` it looks like the range is being ignored which is consistent with what I am experiencing.
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/c76b721d819648431799f9b38bae80e4e2054cf9

However, the ```CompletionItem``` interface in ```vscode-languageserver-node``` does not have a range property. Does that interface need to be updated?

issue.title: metamodel: include message types
issue.body: `RequestMessage`, `ResponseMessage`, and `NotificationMessage` are in the spec but missing from the metamodel. It would be handy to have them for completeness (and every implementation will probably need corresponding types, so we might as well generate them!).

issue.title: metamodel: include message types
issue.body: `RequestMessage`, `ResponseMessage`, and `NotificationMessage` are in the spec but missing from the metamodel. It would be handy to have them for completeness (and every implementation will probably need corresponding types, so we might as well generate them!).

comment.body:
Actually, this is on purpose. These types are defined by JSONRPC and a generation tool could rely on a library to provide them (e.g. even in LSP we have the protocol which depends on vscode-jsonrpc, which defines these types).

I will close the issue since I think that the meta model shouldn't define these.

issue.title: JSON RPC Protocol operator "??"  in compiled js files
issue.body:
### The problem

The package `vscode-jsonrpc` does not comply with the es2018 standard. 

For "proprietary packages" describing the protocol, it would be nice to be able to build parent project without additional library transpilation. Now, to bring it to the es2018 standard, an additional run of all the code through babel or something like that is required.

Compiled file witn issue https://unpkg.com/vscode-jsonrpc@8.0.1/lib/common/connection.js
Source file https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/main/jsonrpc/src/common/connection.ts#L731

### Expectations

Bundled js files shouldn't have `??` or anything non es2018 features.

Phobia test results contains error as well, bcause cannot works witn nullish operator `??` see here https://bundlephobia.com/package/vscode-jsonrpc@8.0.1

issue.title: It's should be possible to `start()` a LanguageClient that failed previously.
issue.body:
My use case is the following:

I have a plugin which will read the settings to start from the configuration (i.e.: executable / arguments), so, whenever those settings are changed, the `LanguageClient` is restarted.

This works well enough, but if the user has some wrong setting (say, he mistyped the executable) then an error will be raised when starting the Language (the `ServerOptions` passed to the `LanguageClient` is a function which is called when the `LanguageClient` is started, but in this case it'll throw an error -- afterwards, trying to call `LanguageClient.start()` or `LanguageClient.stop()` will always just reraise the same error and the function passed as the `ServerOptions` will not be called again).

Tested with `"vscode-languageclient": "^7.0.0"` and `"vscode-languageclient": "^8.0.0-next.7"`.

Note: not sure if it makes a difference, but in this scenario the `LanguageClient` was started successfully once, then the user made changes to make the error happen and then when fixing it to have the proper settings it won't work (because it has failed the previous time and calls to `stop` and `start` just reraise the previous error instead of calling the function passed as `ServerOptions`).

issue.title: It's should be possible to `start()` a LanguageClient that failed previously.
issue.body:
My use case is the following:

I have a plugin which will read the settings to start from the configuration (i.e.: executable / arguments), so, whenever those settings are changed, the `LanguageClient` is restarted.

This works well enough, but if the user has some wrong setting (say, he mistyped the executable) then an error will be raised when starting the Language (the `ServerOptions` passed to the `LanguageClient` is a function which is called when the `LanguageClient` is started, but in this case it'll throw an error -- afterwards, trying to call `LanguageClient.start()` or `LanguageClient.stop()` will always just reraise the same error and the function passed as the `ServerOptions` will not be called again).

Tested with `"vscode-languageclient": "^7.0.0"` and `"vscode-languageclient": "^8.0.0-next.7"`.

Note: not sure if it makes a difference, but in this scenario the `LanguageClient` was started successfully once, then the user made changes to make the error happen and then when fixing it to have the proper settings it won't work (because it has failed the previous time and calls to `stop` and `start` just reraise the previous error instead of calling the function passed as `ServerOptions`).

When ESLint fails to load a plugin it gives 3 suggestions:

```
Failed to load plugin '@typescript-eslint' declared in 'frontend/.eslintrc': Cannot find module '@typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin'
Require stack:
- /Users/brady/Dev/tiamat/member_webapp_frontend/__placeholder__.js

This can happen for a couple of reasons:

issue.title: Allow specifying nearest config directory as working directory

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
Currently, I can specify that the eslint working directory should be
- workspace folder
- linted file directory
- "auto" inferred (the meaning of which is not very clear)
- specific sets of directories or directory globs

Consider a layout for an Angular project that uses Nightwatch for end-to-end testing. Nightwatch uses property names for some configuration options that need to be quoted like e.g. `ms:edgeOptions`. I want to enforce that code we write in typescript uses `camelCase` properties, but the `nigtwatch.conf.js` file (which needs to be JS not TS for reasons I don't understand - but at least that makes the pathspec easy to wildcard) needs to relax that constraint.

So, the directories look like
```
- nightwatch/
    - nightwatch.conf.json
    - .eslintrc.json
    - tsconfig.e2e.json
    - globals/
        - globals.ts
    - page_objects/
        - a-page.ts
    - tests/
        - page.spec.ts
- angular.json
- .eslintrc.json
- tsconfig.json
- package.json
- node_modules/...
- src/
    - app/
        - app.component.ts
    - index.html
```
... where `nightwatch/.eslintrc.json` extends the root `.eslintrc.json`.

And I have a workspace open to the root of this project. To get the Typescript ESLint plugin parser working, I have `overrides[0].parserOptions.project` set to `["tsconfig.e2e.json"]`. Running ESLint manually from within the `nightwatch/` directory picks up all the proper rules and lints appropriately. Running ESLint manually from the project root properly uses the nightwatch config for that directory and the root config for everything else. The ESLint VSCod(e/ium) plugin, however, fails to lint any files under `nightwatch/` because
```
Parsing error: Cannot read file '/path/to/project/root/tsconfig.e2e.json'.
```
(also fwiw `ng lint` works exactly correctly as well).

That's because - I assume - the plugin is trying to run ESLint from the project root but specifying the configuration file as the one in the directory it's trying to lint. As a manual ESLint command, it would look like `npx eslint -c ./nightwatch/.eslintrc.json ./nightwatch `. That command fails with the same messages that the plugin gives me.

Instead, ESLint should allow me to configure it to use the directory containing the `.eslintrc.json` file it's using as the working directory.

Interestingly, in both "location" and "auto" modes, if I change the `nightwatch/.eslintrc.json`'s `overrides[0].parserOptions.project` to `["nightwatch/tsconfig.e2e.json"]`, first of all it starts to successfully lint files under `nightwatch/` - but then if I change that property _back_ to just `["tsconfig.e2e.json"]` it'll keep successfully linting those files. I have no idea why it can "fix" itself like this and only after I manually intervene.

comment.body:
Reading through it again I think there is nothing the extension can do since the working directory determines the search path start not the other way around. The current behavior is as follows:

- no working directories specified: the workspace folder is used as a working directory. The base name of the file path is used as a starting directory for searching for config files / node modules
- a working directory is specified: it is used. The base name of the file path is used as a starting directory for searching for config files / node modules
- auto: The base name of the file path is used as a starting directory for searching for config files / node modules. If a config filer is found in one of the parent directories then that directory is used as a working directory.

I will close the issue. Please ping if you think that the current behavior is not sufficient.

issue.title: Lint task: doesn't work without `node_modules` in workspace folder

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
I am working on a multiplayer game project, and the client- and server-side logic are included in separate root folders of my repository. Only the server-side folder contains TypeScript code, and therefore only that folder has the usual config files like `package.json` and `.eslintrc.js` file, and only that folder has `node_modules/`; there is no `node_modules/` folder at the root. The `lint whole folder` task does not work under these circumstances. Regardless of what paths I pass to the `eslint.options`, `eslint.workingDirectories`, or `eslint.lintTask.options` settings, the task always fails with:

>/usr/bin/bash: eslint: command not found
The terminal process "bash '-c', 'eslint .'" failed to launch (exit code: 127).

Looking through your source, it appears that the issue is in the [utils.findEslint](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-eslint/blob/a0172c8645dd790df32a6c2b6436855eff470775/client/src/utils.ts#L18) function. It looks for `<rootPath>/node_modules/.bin/eslint.cmd` on win32 platforms, else `<rootPath>/node_modules/.bin/eslint` on linux, else a global `eslint`. `<rootPath>`, in turn, is apparently set to the root workspace folder in the [`FolderTaskProvider` constructor](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-eslint/blob/a0172c8645dd790df32a6c2b6436855eff470775/client/src/tasks.ts#L15). So in my setup (repo opened under WSL2 on Windows 10, with no globally installed eslint package), the task fails b/c it can't find the local eslint in my server folder.

I considered opening a PR for this myself, but it will probably require a new config option, and that doesn't seem like my decision to make. 😛 Any other workarounds that I might've missed would be much appreciated!

issue.title: "lint whole folder" task ignores eslint.rules.customizations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
In my settings file I have:
```
"eslint.rules.customizations": [{ "rule": "*", "severity": "downgrade" }]
```

When I run "eslint: lint whole folder", however, eslint errors show up as errors in the Problems panel. If I click on one of those errors, then the offending file is opened, the regular eslint process runs that file, and all issues that were reporting as errors are switched (because of the customizations) to reporting as warnings. Shouldn't the lint whole folder task look at customizations and show those issues as warnings in the first place?

issue.title: Ambiguous "Extension 'ESLint' cannot format x" error if eslint not installed

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
I think that the error you get if you haven't installed eslint is a little ambiguous and making it more specific would help diagnose the problem faster.

I cloned a monorepo which has eslint as a dependency at the top level and then individual packages in subfolders. I remembered to run `npm install` in the sub-package folders but forgot to run it in the root folder. When trying to format a file I was seeing this error:

> Extension 'ESLint' cannot format '*.js'

Opening the eslint output pane I saw nothing to indicate anything was wrong, the complete output was:

> [Info  - 12:13:06 pm] ESLint server stopped.
> [Info  - 12:13:06 pm] ESLint server running in node v14.16.0
> [Info  - 12:13:06 pm] ESLint server is running.

After googling and reading issues for a while I eventually remembered what I'd forgotten to do, but a specific error indicating that eslint was not found in this case would be really helpful for spotting the problem.

issue.body:
Currently, this extension has a `eslint.nodePath` option that allows specifying a known directory for finding the `eslint` executable. This does not solve a very specific problem for me:

I have a project that looks like:

```
❯ tree -L 4
.
├── index.js
├── node_modules
│   └── standard
│       ├── AUTHORS.md
│       ├── CHANGELOG.md
│       ├── LICENSE
│       ├── README.md
│       ├── RULES.md
│       ├── bin
│       │   └── cmd.js
│       ├── eslintrc.json
│       ├── index.js
│       ├── node_modules
│       │   ├── eslint
│       │   ├── eslint-config-standard
│       │   ├── eslint-config-standard-jsx
│       │   ├── eslint-plugin-import
│       │   ├── eslint-plugin-node
│       │   ├── eslint-plugin-promise
│       │   ├── eslint-plugin-react
│       │   └── standard-engine
│       ├── options.js
│       └── package.json
└── package.json

12 directories, 12 files
```

Notice that the `eslint` package is in a nested `node_modules` directory. This means the VSCode extension will not find the executable and thus will not show lint errors or automatically fix errors on save within this project.

What I would like to see is an option like `eslint.searchPaths = []` which could be altered to something like:

```js
eslint.searchPaths = ['built-in', `${workspaceDir}/node_modules/standard/node_modules`]
```

Where the special "buit-in" string would include the current paths that the extension searches.

I think this issue is very similar to #1286 but not quite the same.

---

**.npmrc**
```
save-prefix=^
package-lock=false
```

**package.json**
```json
{
  "devDependencies": {
    "standard": "^16.0.3"
  }
}
```

**index.js**
```js
'use strict';

function thisFileHasLintErrors() {
return true
}

thisFileHasLintErrors()

```

Notice that the `eslint` package is in a nested `node_modules` directory. This means the VSCode extension will not find the executable and thus will not show lint errors or automatically fix errors on save within this project.

eslint.searchPaths = ['built-in', `${workspaceDir}/node_modules/standard/node_modules`]

Where the special "buit-in" string would include the current paths that the extension searches.

I think this issue is very similar to #1286 but not quite the same.

---

save-prefix=^

issue.title: Adding another Disable Rule Comment through VSCode's Quick FIx options causes the rules to be re-enabled
issue.body:
**Problem Statement**
If a disable rule comment has already present for a particular line, and when we add another disable rule comment through vscode's quick-fix option,  a separate new comment is added below the previous one. This causes the previous rule to be re-enabled for the concerned line.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15160343/117317127-dbc72e00-aea6-11eb-8518-62505ad8ebc0.png)

Similar behaviour happens when `eslint.codeAction.disableRuleComment.location` has been set to `sameLine`. The new disable rule comment is appended to the existing disable rule comment present.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15160343/117317421-22b52380-aea7-11eb-82c4-84c49131ca23.png)


**Expected Behaviour**
If there is any preexisting disable rule comment for any particular line and another rule is being disabled for that same line, instead of creating or appending the comment, only the rule should be appended to the existing disable rule comment, separated by comma(s). Like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15160343/117317850-83446080-aea7-11eb-8417-33949fd7f207.png)


The same behavior is observed when disabling multiple rules for entire files as well, but it doesn't cause any rule to be re-enabled

I would like to work on the fix for this too.

issue.title: Generate tsconfig files from higher level description
issue.body: Currently we maintain tsconfig.json and a tsconfig-watch.json configuration file hierarchy. We actually need a third one for publishing since we should publish with different compiler settings. To avoid another hierarchy of settings we need to maintain by hand we should have a generator that creates these configuration files on the fly.

issue.title: Pull diagnostics not cleared when file deleted
issue.body:
With workspace diagnostic support enabled, diagnostics for a file are not cleared when the file is deleted (either through VSCode or externally). The diagnostics remain in the problems tab.

This issue becomes more apparent when using commands like `git stash`

issue.title: The client throws an error `read ECONNRESET` during server debugging
issue.body:
When I step debugging the `completionProvider` of the LSP server and run the `RegExp match`, the LSP client triggers the `handleConnectionError` due to `read ECONNRESET` and the server is stopped.

But this does not happen when I add a break-point on the line following the `RegExp match`.

issue.title: The client throws an error `read ECONNRESET` during server debugging
issue.body:
When I step debugging the `completionProvider` of the LSP server and run the `RegExp match`, the LSP client triggers the `handleConnectionError` due to `read ECONNRESET` and the server is stopped.

But this does not happen when I add a break-point on the line following the `RegExp match`.

issue.title: The initial execution of a Python file is slow again
issue.body: Need to investigate why this is happening again.

comment.body:
Actually,  `vscode-python-web-wasm` will change frequently since it host currently both the default python installation and the extension code. We could move the default python installation into another repository but that would look strange from a repository point of view.

I am actually for option (ii). I do for example load the wasm file into shared memory (and cache it there) so that I don't need to copy it into the worker on every run. Since a sync can happen at any time I would need to drop the WASM file again and reload it into shared memory. For that I would need the event.

issue.title: Perform websocket request during onDefinition
issue.body:
When `connection.onDefinition` is invoked, I'm hoping to send a websocket request and await its response before returning the definition `Location`, which takes the user to that location in VS Code. The execution of `connection.onDefinition` completes before the websocket request/response finishes.

I've experimented with using a callback function. First, by having the callback return the desired `Location`, but that does not trigger that location to open in VS Code. Secondly, I tried having the callback invoke `connection.onDefinition` with updated parameters, and making sure to return the `Location` in this case, but that also does not jump the user to the definition location.

Is it possible to achieve this? Or is there simply no way currently to delay the execution of `connection.onDefinition` or invoke it a subsequent time using a callback function?

comment.body: Yes all request callback can return a Promise which will be awaited before the response is sent back.

issue.title: Header field name in jsonrpc Message has to be case-insensitive
issue.body:
Hi! I'm working on building protobuf language server in Deno and its extension for vscode.

I found that the header part of LSP message conforms to the HTTP semantic in [LSP docs](https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/specification-3-17/#headerPart).

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/f72faa0975cb2aaa85ce84da819944f84e1aac52/jsonrpc/src/common/messageBuffer.ts#L94
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/f72faa0975cb2aaa85ce84da819944f84e1aac52/jsonrpc/src/common/messageReader.ts#L218
But `tryReadHeaders` and its usage in `messageReader` show that the header field name seems to be case-sensitive.

I think the return object of `tryReadHeaders` has to be implemented like `Headers` in Web API, or any other object that can get a header value with case-insensitive name.

issue.title: Working extension inexplicably stopped sending document symbols
issue.body:
I'm working on developing an extension for VSCode that utilizes this language server library. I've gotten to the point where I'm able to successfully respond to the `onDocumentSymbol()` hook. [Here's the server.ts file in my repo](https://github.com/japhib/pico8-ls/blob/master/server/src/server.ts) -- a fairly simple implementation, following [this guide](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/language-extensions/language-server-extension-guide).

However, after getting it to work in my test workspace, the "go to symbol" action then mysteriously _stopped_ working. No indication of an error -- no loading indicator, no "symbols are not available," just "no editor symbols." 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11890284/150730396-f06f5654-2643-4da1-bbdc-9970cd3b697b.png)

If I enable tracing for my extension, I can clearly see the document symbol request getting sent to my language server, and then returned back to the extension client with a huge list of symbols for the file I had open.

I had made some code changes, but when I reverted all those code changes and went back to the previous state of the repo, **it still did not work.**

So I thought, alright, maybe there's some config in my VSCode or something about the installation got in a weird place. So I went ahead and uninstalled VSCode completely (I'm on mac, so I deleted it from /Applications/ and also `rm -rf`'ed a bunch of folders [as described here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42603103/how-to-completely-uninstall-vscode-on-mac)) and then re-installed it. I'm still getting the same behavior after re-installation.

The really vexing thing is that as soon as I try it on another computer, **it still works.** Just like I had it working before. I get a big list of document symbols exactly as expected.

So my question is, how do I even begin debugging this? Is there some verbose error logging I can enable? Do I need to clone this repo locally, reference it in my project, and add a bunch of `console.log`? Any suggestions appreciated. I'm also happy to provide more details if needed. Thanks.

commits.message:
Some small bug fixes (#1137)

* Fixes #886: Working extension inexplicably stopped sending document symbols

* Fixes #897: Header field name in jsonrpc Message has to be case-insensitive

issue.title: Stream read errors result in uncaught exceptions
issue.body:
`ReadableStreamMessageReader` throws exceptions if `Content-Length` is invalid, which end up as uncaught exceptions instead of going through `onError`. See the tests in #871 for an example. Without the try/catch, the test fails:

```
  1) Messages
       Read without Content-Length:
     Uncaught Error: Header must provide a Content-Length property.
      at StreamMessageReader.onData (lib/common/messageReader.js:137:27)
      at Readable.<anonymous> (lib/common/messageReader.js:121:18)
      at Readable.read (_stream_readable.js:512:10)
      at flow (_stream_readable.js:985:34)
      at resume_ (_stream_readable.js:966:3)
      at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:84:21)

  2) Messages
       Read with invalid Content-Length:
     Uncaught Error: Content-Length value must be a number.
      at StreamMessageReader.onData (lib/common/messageReader.js:141:27)
      at Readable.<anonymous> (lib/common/messageReader.js:121:18)
      at Readable.read (_stream_readable.js:512:10)
      at flow (_stream_readable.js:985:34)
      at resume_ (_stream_readable.js:966:3)
      at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:84:21)
```

This was previously reported in #270, but it has not been fixed.

issue.title: Inconsistent Interface for CompletionItem
issue.body:
What is the intended approach to create a ```CompletionItem``` that replaces text?

I would like the completion to replace the entire line where the users cursor is currently located.

When I specify the text and range as a ```TextEdit``` the range seems to be ignored and instead the default current word range is used.
```
const completionItem = {
    label: 'competion item label',
    kind: CompletionItemKind.Text,
    textEdit: TextEdit.replace('new text', range),
}
```

I did a little digging and it looks like in the VS Code API interfaces ```textEdit``` is deprecated with the message ```Use `CompletionItem.insertText` and `CompletionItem.range` instead.```
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vscode-dts/vscode.d.ts#L4515

In the commit that deprecated ```textEdit``` it looks like the range is being ignored which is consistent with what I am experiencing.
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/c76b721d819648431799f9b38bae80e4e2054cf9

However, the ```CompletionItem``` interface in ```vscode-languageserver-node``` does not have a range property. Does that interface need to be updated?

issue.title: metamodel: include message types
issue.body: `RequestMessage`, `ResponseMessage`, and `NotificationMessage` are in the spec but missing from the metamodel. It would be handy to have them for completeness (and every implementation will probably need corresponding types, so we might as well generate them!).

issue.title: metamodel: include message types
issue.body: `RequestMessage`, `ResponseMessage`, and `NotificationMessage` are in the spec but missing from the metamodel. It would be handy to have them for completeness (and every implementation will probably need corresponding types, so we might as well generate them!).

comment.body:
Actually, this is on purpose. These types are defined by JSONRPC and a generation tool could rely on a library to provide them (e.g. even in LSP we have the protocol which depends on vscode-jsonrpc, which defines these types).

I will close the issue since I think that the meta model shouldn't define these.

issue.title: JSON RPC Protocol operator "??"  in compiled js files
issue.body:
### The problem

The package `vscode-jsonrpc` does not comply with the es2018 standard. 

For "proprietary packages" describing the protocol, it would be nice to be able to build parent project without additional library transpilation. Now, to bring it to the es2018 standard, an additional run of all the code through babel or something like that is required.

Compiled file witn issue https://unpkg.com/vscode-jsonrpc@8.0.1/lib/common/connection.js
Source file https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/main/jsonrpc/src/common/connection.ts#L731

### Expectations

Bundled js files shouldn't have `??` or anything non es2018 features.

Phobia test results contains error as well, bcause cannot works witn nullish operator `??` see here https://bundlephobia.com/package/vscode-jsonrpc@8.0.1

comment.body: I changed the way how I maintain the tsconfig files. There is now a `.tsconfigrc.js` file which with minimal effort can be used to produce an es2018 compatible version. Since the jsonrpc package is specific to `vscode` I would like to keep the `es2020` target since this is what VS Code uses as well. I will therefore close the issue.

issue.title: It's should be possible to `start()` a LanguageClient that failed previously.
issue.body:
My use case is the following:

I have a plugin which will read the settings to start from the configuration (i.e.: executable / arguments), so, whenever those settings are changed, the `LanguageClient` is restarted.

This works well enough, but if the user has some wrong setting (say, he mistyped the executable) then an error will be raised when starting the Language (the `ServerOptions` passed to the `LanguageClient` is a function which is called when the `LanguageClient` is started, but in this case it'll throw an error -- afterwards, trying to call `LanguageClient.start()` or `LanguageClient.stop()` will always just reraise the same error and the function passed as the `ServerOptions` will not be called again).

Tested with `"vscode-languageclient": "^7.0.0"` and `"vscode-languageclient": "^8.0.0-next.7"`.

Note: not sure if it makes a difference, but in this scenario the `LanguageClient` was started successfully once, then the user made changes to make the error happen and then when fixing it to have the proper settings it won't work (because it has failed the previous time and calls to `stop` and `start` just reraise the previous error instead of calling the function passed as `ServerOptions`).

issue.title: Improve 'Failed to load plugin' error feedback

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
When ESLint fails to load a plugin it gives 3 suggestions:

```
Failed to load plugin '@typescript-eslint' declared in 'frontend/.eslintrc': Cannot find module '@typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin'
Require stack:
- /Users/brady/Dev/tiamat/member_webapp_frontend/__placeholder__.js
Referenced from: /Users/brady/Dev/tiamat/member_webapp_frontend/frontend/.eslintrc
Happened while validating /Users/brady/Dev/tiamat/member_webapp_frontend/frontend/src/modules/admin/pages/tests/AdminReportsPage.test.tsx
This can happen for a couple of reasons:

1. The plugin name is spelled incorrectly in an ESLint configuration file (e.g. .eslintrc).
2. If ESLint is installed globally, then make sure '@typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin' is installed globally as well.
3. If ESLint is installed locally, then '@typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin' isn't installed correctly.

Consider running eslint --debug /Users/brady/Dev/tiamat/member_webapp_frontend/frontend/src/modules/admin/pages/tests/AdminReportsPage.test.tsx from a terminal to obtain a trace about the configuration files used.
```

The plugin should be aware of where ESLint is being loaded in from, global or local, so feedback here should be more specific. It could say where eslint is being loaded in from and the locations it checked for the plugin that's failing to load.

In my case, eslint is not installed globally and it is installed locally so I checked my `node_modules/@typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin` directory to make sure it exists and it does. Running the final command that's suggested succeeds with no issues so I don't really know where to go from here.

.eslintrc file contents:
```
{
  "ignorePatterns": [
    "src/generated/*.*",
    "src/**/*.generated.tsx"
  ],
  "extends": [
    "react-app",
    "plugin:@typescript-eslint/recommended",
    "plugin:jest-dom/recommended",
    "plugin:testing-library/react",
    "plugin:prettier/recommended"
  ],
  "plugins": [
    "testing-library",
    "prettier"
  ],
  "root": true,
  "rules": {
    "prettier/prettier": ["error"],
    "no-console": "error",
    "react-hooks/exhaustive-deps": 0,
    "react/jsx-key": "error",
    "import/no-default-export": "off",
    "@typescript-eslint/explicit-function-return-type": "off",
    "@typescript-eslint/no-empty-function": "off",
    "@typescript-eslint/explicit-module-boundary-types": "off",
    "@typescript-eslint/no-unused-vars": [
      "error",
      {
        "varsIgnorePattern": "^_",
        "argsIgnorePattern": "^_"
      }
    ],
    "no-unused-expressions": "off",
    "@typescript-eslint/no-unused-expressions": "error",
    "jest-dom/prefer-in-document": "off",
    "testing-library/prefer-find-by": "off",
    "prefer-spread": "off",
    "jsx-a11y/alt-text": "warn",
    "array-callback-return": "off",
    "@typescript-eslint/prefer-as-const": "off",
    "testing-library/no-await-sync-query": "off",
    "testing-library/prefer-screen-queries": "off",
    "@typescript-eslint/no-inferrable-types": "off",
    "@typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any": "warn",
    "eqeqeq": [
      "warn",
      "smart"
    ],
    "@typescript-eslint/ban-types": [
      "error",
      {
        "extendDefaults": true,
        "types": {
          "{}": false
        }
      }
    ]
  }
}
```

settings.json
```
{
    "eslint.validate": [
        "css",
        "html",
        "markdown",
        "javascript",
        "javascriptreact",
        "typescript",
        "typescriptreact",
    ]
}
```

**Note:** I worked around _my_ issue when I changed the workspace root to be the module root (where node_modules is located) but it would be nice not to have to do that and I just stumbled upon this solution because I'm experience with ESLint and have seen this before. I'd still like to get ESLint working without changing the workspace root.

issue.title: Allow specifying nearest config directory as working directory

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
Currently, I can specify that the eslint working directory should be
- workspace folder
- linted file directory
- "auto" inferred (the meaning of which is not very clear)
- specific sets of directories or directory globs

Consider a layout for an Angular project that uses Nightwatch for end-to-end testing. Nightwatch uses property names for some configuration options that need to be quoted like e.g. `ms:edgeOptions`. I want to enforce that code we write in typescript uses `camelCase` properties, but the `nigtwatch.conf.js` file (which needs to be JS not TS for reasons I don't understand - but at least that makes the pathspec easy to wildcard) needs to relax that constraint.

So, the directories look like
```
- nightwatch/
    - nightwatch.conf.json
    - .eslintrc.json
    - tsconfig.e2e.json
    - globals/
        - globals.ts
    - page_objects/
        - a-page.ts
    - tests/
        - page.spec.ts
- angular.json
- .eslintrc.json
- tsconfig.json
- package.json
- node_modules/...
- src/
    - app/
        - app.component.ts
    - index.html
```
... where `nightwatch/.eslintrc.json` extends the root `.eslintrc.json`.

And I have a workspace open to the root of this project. To get the Typescript ESLint plugin parser working, I have `overrides[0].parserOptions.project` set to `["tsconfig.e2e.json"]`. Running ESLint manually from within the `nightwatch/` directory picks up all the proper rules and lints appropriately. Running ESLint manually from the project root properly uses the nightwatch config for that directory and the root config for everything else. The ESLint VSCod(e/ium) plugin, however, fails to lint any files under `nightwatch/` because
```
Parsing error: Cannot read file '/path/to/project/root/tsconfig.e2e.json'.
```
(also fwiw `ng lint` works exactly correctly as well).

That's because - I assume - the plugin is trying to run ESLint from the project root but specifying the configuration file as the one in the directory it's trying to lint. As a manual ESLint command, it would look like `npx eslint -c ./nightwatch/.eslintrc.json ./nightwatch `. That command fails with the same messages that the plugin gives me.

Instead, ESLint should allow me to configure it to use the directory containing the `.eslintrc.json` file it's using as the working directory.

Interestingly, in both "location" and "auto" modes, if I change the `nightwatch/.eslintrc.json`'s `overrides[0].parserOptions.project` to `["nightwatch/tsconfig.e2e.json"]`, first of all it starts to successfully lint files under `nightwatch/` - but then if I change that property _back_ to just `["tsconfig.e2e.json"]` it'll keep successfully linting those files. I have no idea why it can "fix" itself like this and only after I manually intervene.

comment.body:
Reading through it again I think there is nothing the extension can do since the working directory determines the search path start not the other way around. The current behavior is as follows:

- no working directories specified: the workspace folder is used as a working directory. The base name of the file path is used as a starting directory for searching for config files / node modules
- a working directory is specified: it is used. The base name of the file path is used as a starting directory for searching for config files / node modules
- auto: The base name of the file path is used as a starting directory for searching for config files / node modules. If a config filer is found in one of the parent directories then that directory is used as a working directory.

I will close the issue. Please ping if you think that the current behavior is not sufficient.

issue.title: Lint task: doesn't work without `node_modules` in workspace folder

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
I am working on a multiplayer game project, and the client- and server-side logic are included in separate root folders of my repository. Only the server-side folder contains TypeScript code, and therefore only that folder has the usual config files like `package.json` and `.eslintrc.js` file, and only that folder has `node_modules/`; there is no `node_modules/` folder at the root. The `lint whole folder` task does not work under these circumstances. Regardless of what paths I pass to the `eslint.options`, `eslint.workingDirectories`, or `eslint.lintTask.options` settings, the task always fails with:

>/usr/bin/bash: eslint: command not found
The terminal process "bash '-c', 'eslint .'" failed to launch (exit code: 127).

Looking through your source, it appears that the issue is in the [utils.findEslint](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-eslint/blob/a0172c8645dd790df32a6c2b6436855eff470775/client/src/utils.ts#L18) function. It looks for `<rootPath>/node_modules/.bin/eslint.cmd` on win32 platforms, else `<rootPath>/node_modules/.bin/eslint` on linux, else a global `eslint`. `<rootPath>`, in turn, is apparently set to the root workspace folder in the [`FolderTaskProvider` constructor](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-eslint/blob/a0172c8645dd790df32a6c2b6436855eff470775/client/src/tasks.ts#L15). So in my setup (repo opened under WSL2 on Windows 10, with no globally installed eslint package), the task fails b/c it can't find the local eslint in my server folder.

I considered opening a PR for this myself, but it will probably require a new config option, and that doesn't seem like my decision to make. 😛 Any other workarounds that I might've missed would be much appreciated!

issue.title: "lint whole folder" task ignores eslint.rules.customizations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
In my settings file I have:
```
"eslint.rules.customizations": [{ "rule": "*", "severity": "downgrade" }]
```

When I run "eslint: lint whole folder", however, eslint errors show up as errors in the Problems panel. If I click on one of those errors, then the offending file is opened, the regular eslint process runs that file, and all issues that were reporting as errors are switched (because of the customizations) to reporting as warnings. Shouldn't the lint whole folder task look at customizations and show those issues as warnings in the first place?

issue.title: Ambiguous "Extension 'ESLint' cannot format x" error if eslint not installed

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
I think that the error you get if you haven't installed eslint is a little ambiguous and making it more specific would help diagnose the problem faster.

I cloned a monorepo which has eslint as a dependency at the top level and then individual packages in subfolders. I remembered to run `npm install` in the sub-package folders but forgot to run it in the root folder. When trying to format a file I was seeing this error:

> Extension 'ESLint' cannot format '*.js'

Opening the eslint output pane I saw nothing to indicate anything was wrong, the complete output was:

> [Info  - 12:13:06 pm] ESLint server stopped.
> [Info  - 12:13:06 pm] ESLint server running in node v14.16.0
> [Info  - 12:13:06 pm] ESLint server is running.

After googling and reading issues for a while I eventually remembered what I'd forgotten to do, but a specific error indicating that eslint was not found in this case would be really helpful for spotting the problem.

issue.title: Add a "search paths" option

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

issue.body:
Currently, this extension has a `eslint.nodePath` option that allows specifying a known directory for finding the `eslint` executable. This does not solve a very specific problem for me:

I have a project that looks like:

```
❯ tree -L 4
.
├── index.js
├── node_modules
│   └── standard
│       ├── AUTHORS.md
│       ├── CHANGELOG.md
│       ├── LICENSE
│       ├── README.md
│       ├── RULES.md
│       ├── bin
│       │   └── cmd.js
│       ├── eslintrc.json
│       ├── index.js
│       ├── node_modules
│       │   ├── eslint
│       │   ├── eslint-config-standard
│       │   ├── eslint-config-standard-jsx
│       │   ├── eslint-plugin-import
│       │   ├── eslint-plugin-node
│       │   ├── eslint-plugin-promise
│       │   ├── eslint-plugin-react
│       │   └── standard-engine
│       ├── options.js
│       └── package.json
└── package.json

12 directories, 12 files
```

Notice that the `eslint` package is in a nested `node_modules` directory. This means the VSCode extension will not find the executable and thus will not show lint errors or automatically fix errors on save within this project.

What I would like to see is an option like `eslint.searchPaths = []` which could be altered to something like:

```js
eslint.searchPaths = ['built-in', `${workspaceDir}/node_modules/standard/node_modules`]
```

Where the special "buit-in" string would include the current paths that the extension searches.

I think this issue is very similar to #1286 but not quite the same.

---

**.npmrc**
```
save-prefix=^
package-lock=false
```

**package.json**
```json
{
  "devDependencies": {
    "standard": "^16.0.3"
  }
}
```

**index.js**
```js
'use strict';

function thisFileHasLintErrors() {
return true
}

thisFileHasLintErrors()

```

issue.title: Adding another Disable Rule Comment through VSCode's Quick FIx options causes the rules to be re-enabled
issue.body:
**Problem Statement**
If a disable rule comment has already present for a particular line, and when we add another disable rule comment through vscode's quick-fix option,  a separate new comment is added below the previous one. This causes the previous rule to be re-enabled for the concerned line.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15160343/117317127-dbc72e00-aea6-11eb-8518-62505ad8ebc0.png)

Similar behaviour happens when `eslint.codeAction.disableRuleComment.location` has been set to `sameLine`. The new disable rule comment is appended to the existing disable rule comment present.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15160343/117317421-22b52380-aea7-11eb-82c4-84c49131ca23.png)


**Expected Behaviour**
If there is any preexisting disable rule comment for any particular line and another rule is being disabled for that same line, instead of creating or appending the comment, only the rule should be appended to the existing disable rule comment, separated by comma(s). Like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15160343/117317850-83446080-aea7-11eb-8417-33949fd7f207.png)


The same behavior is observed when disabling multiple rules for entire files as well, but it doesn't cause any rule to be re-enabled

I would like to work on the fix for this too.
